sentence-detokenized: The European Union has rejected Germany's call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.
Germany's representative to the EU veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy lamb from countries other than the UK until the scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we see no reason for it," Commission chief spokesperson Nikolaus van der Pas told a press conference.
He said that further scientific studies are needed and if it is found that action is needed, it should be taken by the EU.

He said last month's proposal by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord from the human and animal food chain was a very specific and precautionary measure to protect human health.
Mr Fischler proposed EU-wide measures after reports from the UK and France that under laboratory conditions, sheep can contract Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease.

But Fischler agreed to revisit his proposal after the EU's standing veterinary committee, the national animal health officials, questioned whether the measure was justified as there was little risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio earlier accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing unjustified concern through "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU scientific and multidisciplinary veterinary committee will re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to have scrapie, a brain decay disease similar to BSE, which is believed to have been transferred to cattle through feed containing animal faeces.

British farmers on Thursday denied any danger to human health from their sheep, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"What we have to look at very carefully is how other countries will take Germany's lead," Welsh National Farmers Union (NFU) chairman John Lloyd Jones said on BBC radio.

Bonn has been leading efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a UK report suggested that humans could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of total imports.
It carries 4,275 tonnes of British mutton, about 10 per cent of overall imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sold for nearly $17,000.
A rare handwritten draft of a song by US guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A restaurant in Florida paid 10,925 pounds ($16,935) for the manuscript of "Ain't no telling", which Hendrix wrote on a piece of hotel stationery in London in late 1966.
At the end of a January 1967 concert in the English city of Nottingham, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, where it was picked up by a fan.
Buyers also snapped up 16 other items auctioned off by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend, Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
This includes a black lacquer and pearl inlaid box used by Hendrix to store his medicines, which was bought by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere of the talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for the resumption of talks on the Taiwan Strait with Taiwan Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week that angered Beijing.

Speaking just hours after Chinese state media said the time was right to engage in political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters: "The atmosphere necessary for the opening of talks has been disturbed by Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a visiting group from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the two sides to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to engage in political talks...
that is to end the state of hostilities," Thursday's overseas edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying.

Shen of the foreign ministry told Reuters Television in an interview that he had read reports about Tang's comments, but gave no details on why the negotiator considered the time appropriate for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all of Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwan Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says time is right for Taiwan talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China says it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps towards that goal.

Consultations should be held to set the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, as saying on Wednesday evening.
July German car registrations rose 14.2 per cent yr/yr.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
First-time motor vehicle registrations in Germany jumped 14.2 per cent in July this year from the year-earlier period, the Federal Office for Motor Vehicles said on Thursday.
The office said 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures represent a 13.6 per cent increase for passenger cars and a 2.2 per cent decrease for trucks from July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations rose 32.7 per cent during the period.
The growth was partly due to an increase in the number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said that domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German carmakers posted a profit in registration numbers in the period.
Volkswagen AG won 77,719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Opel AG together with General Motors are in second place with 49,269 registrations, 16.4 per cent of the overall figure.
Third was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7 per cent.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to July last year.
Seat posted 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 registrations in July the previous year.
Porsche registrations dropped to 554 from 643.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE PM THE GREEN LIGHT FOR GENERAL ELECTIONS.
The executive bureau of Greece's socialist party gave the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call snap elections, its general secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

Israel plays down fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries seem to be a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador to Washington conducted fruitless negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it seems Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that Syria's priority {(1)[MISC] is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they are certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is basically a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovich ended his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, Israel's former envoy to Egypt and a right-wing Likud party politician.
Israel on Wednesday sent a message to Syria, via Washington, saying that it is committed to peace and wants to open negotiations without preconditions.
But it criticised Damascus for creating what it called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria accused Israel on Wednesday of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus recently test-fired a missile.
It is said that its arms purchases are for defence purposes.

"The message we are sending to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready at any time without preconditions to enter peace negotiations," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy told Israel Radio in an interview.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June vowing to defend the Golan Heights that Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks have been deadlocked over the Golan since 1991 despite previous governments being willing to make Golan concessions.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
full of expressions and declarations that should be alarming...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect from Syria, if its face is peace, that it will answer Israel's message to enter peace negotiations because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want a war, God forbid.
No one benefits from war. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent "calming signals" to Israel.
The report did not provide a source for the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm it.
The television also said that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria via Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies any nurses stranded in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied Polish tabloid reports this week that Libya denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

To date, we are not aware of any nurses stranded or detained in Libya against their will, and we have not received any complaints," the charge d'affaires of the Polish embassy in Tripoli, Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, told Reuters by phone.

Poland's labour ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the probe was prompted by some nurses complaining about their working conditions such as their unpaid salaries.
He said that there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq vowed on Thursday to extend support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian forces deep inside Iraq last month.

A Khalq Mujahideen statement said its leader Massoud Rajavi met in Baghdad with Democratic Kurdistan Party of Iran (KDPI) Secretary General Hassan Rastegar on Wednesday and voiced his support for the Iranian Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi emphasised that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand side by side with their Kurdish counterparts and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," he said.
A spokesman for the group said that the meeting "signalled a new level of co-operation between the Khalq Mujahideen and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
Iran bombarded targets in northern Iraq in July in pursuit of KDPI militants based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside government control in Baghdad.
The Kurdish areas of Iraq bordering Iran are under the control of the guerrilla group Patriotic Union of Iraqi Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Democratic Party of Iraqi Kurdistan (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were ousted from Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides broke out at the weekend in the most serious fighting since last year's US-sponsored ceasefire.
The Khalq Mujahideen said Iranian forces have also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
It said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey launched air and ground attacks on targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their own Kurdish rebels.
US-led air forces in southern Turkey are protecting Iraqi Kurds from a possible attack by Baghdad forces.
The Saudi riyal exchange rate stabilised in quiet summer trading.
Spot Saudi riyal against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates were largely stable this week in quiet summer trading, dealers in the kingdom said.
"There is no change in the Saudi riyal exchange rate.
The market is very quiet due to the summer holidays," said a dealer.
The spot riyal settled at 3.7504/06 against the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three-month 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six-month 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
One-year funds are at six, 5-7/8 per cent.
Israel approved Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission on Thursday to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief Israel-PLO crisis, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem has been solved.
The president's plane has received permission to pass through Israeli airspace but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat had been scheduled to meet with former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the meeting place was changed to Gaza after Israel denied a flying permit for the Palestinian leader's helicopter.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat in place.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials, for civil affairs, at the Allenby Bridge that crosses between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat had decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, after Israel lifted the ban, because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat will meet Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said Israel's right-wing government had barred the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that he believes that the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy geared towards ensuring economic growth remains unchanged following the release of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
